text: I really enjoy version 1—the movement of the texture gives it this fluid feel and an illusion of depth, which is fun to watch. However, if we want a more spray paint feel, not migrating the texture creates more of that feel, like the colors are being applied to a surface.

I agree. Something about the particle movement makes it feel so much more immersive and mesmerizing (though currently a bit too heavy imo). But the spray paint thing is fundamentally different in look and feel. We kind of have two poles defined for aesthetic inspiration, one for atmospheric haziness, and one for texture heavy spray paint… wondering where this should land, on one, the other, or in between.
Is the texture more clear on the device? I know exporting to video can blur the subtle textures.
#1 is so beautiful :')
i compressed the video to be able to share
it’s much clearer live on the device
personal preference is for #1 as well, although there’s also something interesting about #3

Also Trent on the last question you posed, I wonder if before getting ahead of what potential new increments would might create, we pose that to Adam to have them ask/test with users during the longer term testing that is planned so we can see if that thinking is needed and be better informed if/when we do it.
I think that’s a great idea Abby
We currently have no data to inform what a good average active minute mark is… and have asked them in the past with little informed feedback
I think testing that will be key
It truly is a matter of changing a single number to adjust these brackets so it wouldn’t be a matter of making significant changes
That’s awesome to know

Hey Trent, these look great. I agree with folks about #1. in #2, the texture looks like an add-on (which i guess it kind of is) but in the first, it looks like it's part of the system. Same with #3 — it also feels alive — but I think i prefer the first.
question: do the colors transition/progress in the same way for all three?
yes they do, just different ways of animating the texture
cool. it's looking really good. I love the cadence of the milestones
#2 actually has separate texture assets mapping to each layer visible, fading in and out, but since it doesn’t move, it doesn’t look much different than a single add on texture
yeah we can slow it down/speed it up if necessary but this felt like a good pace to start

<@U026E0ZNR> agree with everyone on #1. These explorations are all great. Thanks for all your work on them. 

Re: milestones, it’s generally recommended to aim for at least 30min of physical activity per day as a baseline. I think that the longitudinal testing will do a better job than any of our guesswork on what the right number of transitions within an average day should be. Like you said, the value is easy enough to change. I would want to make sure that if we do change it (to 15 or 20min, for example) that the new milestone is meaningful in some way. 

Looking at my Google Fit data from the last month or so, I rarely exceed 60min on work days, but my weekends tend to be at least 60min, and sometimes >5hrs. When thinking about how we define milestones, we’ll need to find a balance between providing visual reward on the day scale and being able to visualize patterns on the week or month scale.
late to the party, but am also split between #1 and 3 based on nothing but they look pretty interesting and feel alive with some depth.
thanks for posting them Trent. Really cool to see

text: :thumbsup:

thought i responded to all this earlier but got sidetracked. thanks for all the input everyone. I’ll upload a new update for option 1 by EOD. <@U0260V1BX> that all makes sense to me and 30 min milestones have always seemed the most logical in light of similar apps. I think the question ultimately stems from seeing how beautiful the full progression is and how much of a bummer it would be for a notable chunk of users to potentially never see more than 2 or 3. again, fine the way it is but wanted to test the waters on a quicker progression through the system. it’s easy to duplicate the stack of color layers to create a 2nd, even 3rd loop if we wanted to extend that max cap any further.

hah, this is definitely nerdy but I was talking to Ali about how it’s sort of like how Pokemon Go stopped being fun for a lot of people once they realized most the time you couldn’t find more than the top 5 most common pokemon, there were 145 other ones but attaining them felt too difficult and it wasn’t as interesting anymore

Oh! one more important question <!here|@here>: Is there a desire to keep the double tap to replay feature? most people have been really turned off by the quick progression of this visualization, so it would likely need to move slow like in the video clips. thoughts?
yeah that is a very interesting analogy and i do know what you mean there. if all i see is grey and light blue its gonna get old fast
personally i think the double-tap to replay can die with the sticks. Curious to hear what others think.

I’m about to share these three different options with Scott and Zara, I’ll let them know we mostly favor Option 1 and see what they come back with.
